instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_RSMRST_L: What is PM_RSMRST_L? The "PM_RSMRST_L" signal, also known as "Resume Reset," is an active-low signal that is part of the power management system in MacBooks. It asserts a reset signal when it is low voltage which is what the _L is for. Is the machine is in a reset stage it will not properly power on..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.5V_S5: What is 5V_S5? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S5” which is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Minor liquid damage around clock area, but board was still working. I replaced the really nasty looking stuff just to be safe. Now board doesn't work at all. :(:mad: Going down the power rail list I found that <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL> is at .015V and is supposed to be a 12V rail.

<TRANSISTOR>Q7979</TRANSISTOR> Measurements

pins 1,2,3 @ 12.51V
pin 4 @ 11.70V
pin 5 @ 0.015V
 Resistance on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>, 97.4K 

Thank! a good one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL> is at .015V"
Did you measure with trackpad connected?
However, that voltage is not required for the board to turn on.

Which components did you change?
Check all of them and their traces.
Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S5</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_RSMRST_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> or/and other voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Thanks for the info on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL> not needed for turn on.
I just went back to the area and noticed that I have PPVRTC @ 3.3V on pin1 of <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> but PPVRTC goes down to 2.7V by the time it gets to <CAPACITOR>C8090</CAPACITOR>/1/2. This is most likely my problem?

I replaced <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, Y1905 and surrounding components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I think I found it. I have poor continuity between pad 1 of <CAPACITOR>C1910</CAPACITOR> and the rest of PPVRTC components. Will run a wire and see what happens. Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message: That was it. Im all set. Thanks for the help. Much appreciated!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Missing <SIGNAL>PPBUS_X239_REG</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Unfortunately i think I spoke too soon...

I have 1.8V on <SIGNAL>PPVCC_SO_CPU</SIGNAL> but no post /no chime/no video. No light on USB Mouse either. 

I dont have an O scope so all I can give are Voltages on <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, sry.
Also all signals seem to be properly reaching their destination. 

[url]https://photos.app.goo.gl/sQpgxDPehjNw5Egq8[/url]


<CHIP>U1900</CHIP>
pin 1 - 3.324V
pin 2 - 3.324V
pin 3 - .965V
pin 4 - 1.18V - 1.2V
pin 5 - 3.325V
pin 12 - .324V
pin 13 - 3.405V

Y1905
pin 1 - .960V
pin 3 - 1.208V

Thank you. have a good one!
